definitions.definition: to change something good into something bad, unpleasant, etc.

examples.text: Our camping trip was spoilt by bad weather.
Don't let him spoil your evening.
The tall buildings have spoiled the view.
Don't eat too many nuts—you'll **spoil your appetite** *(= will no longer be hungry at the proper time to eat)*.
I won’t tell you what happens in the last chapter—I don’t want to spoil it for you.
Don't let the bad weather spoil your trip.
Her selfish behaviour completely spoiled the evening.
I don't want to spoil things for everyone else.
It would be a pity to spoil the surprise.
Now, don't be hard on the children and spoil their fun!
The bad weather really spoilt things for us.
Why did they have to act so aggressively and spoil everything?
I don't want to spoil your fun, but it's nearly time to go home.
The new buildings have completely spoiled the view.
The performance was spoilt by the constant noise from the audience.
Why do you always have to spoil everything?

definitions.definition: to give a child everything that they ask for and not enough discipline in a way that has a bad effect on their character and behaviour

examples.text: She spoils those kids of hers.
My grandparents used to **spoil me rotten**.
He spoils the children with expensive toys.
Those children are thoroughly spoiled!

definitions.definition: to make somebody/yourself happy by doing something special

examples.text: Why not spoil yourself with a weekend in a top hotel?
He really spoiled me on my birthday.

definitions.definition: to become bad so that it can no longer be eaten
to mark a ballot paper in a way that is not correct so the vote does not count, especially as a form of protest

examples.text: The group called on its supporters to spoil their ballot papers.

definitions.definition: to want to fight with somebody very much
to cause something good to fail because you did not spend a small but necessary amount of money or time on a small but essential part of it
if too many people are involved in doing something, it will not be done well

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘to plunder’): shortening of Old French espoille (noun), espoillier (verb), from Latin spoliare, from spolium ‘plunder, skin stripped from an animal’, or a shortening of despoil.
